comment.body: Yes, I plan to write something — but not as often as you and Erkan. ;)

@musickiller if you manage to install it on your phone, make sure you replace all instances of `.DEBUG` with `.INFO` in `src/main.py` — otherwise the logfile will become too big.

Personally, I think ZeroNet will be too hard on the battery if installed on a phone or a tablet, so I put my faith in setting up a proxy so that I can access it on my mobile when I'm out.

The app itself is unchanged from the original one, except the stylesheet has been moved to the <body/>. I think I will leave it that way. But we can [link to the drawbacks](https://github.com/diafygi/mylock#user-content-drawbacks) here.
Btw, is there an upper limit for the size of ZeroNet apps? I would like to put the note-taking app [Laverna](https://laverna.cc/) on Zeronet, but the main js file weighs in at 1.4 MB.
Thanks!

Haha, redistributed network. That's a good one! :)

Well, ZeroName can query the NameCoin blockchain, so surely it would be possible to query an NXT instance also.

You can visit http://localhost:7876/test if you want to see all NXT's API calls.

(On Hyperboria, somebody used the NXT aliases for registering .hype domains, the same way NameCoin is used to register .bit domains, btw.)
I found it like that when I arrived at the scene of the crime, but it must have been an experience for those who were there when it happened.
I believe the cops were already involved.

> the picture is old =D

Yes, but it still makes me smile. :)

> to make it clickable you should use "a" tag still

Is there no way to make it clickable without using an <a/>-tag?

> I had to think of fractals, somehow when I saw this pic

Yes, it reminds me of fractals, too!

I did check `name_show` before I issued the `name_new`, yes. And yes, there's a possibility that someone else did a `name_new` on that domain before I did, and never did a `name_firstupdate`, but it's unlikely.

The `name_new`, once accepted, is it valid for 36'000 blocks like a fully confirmed `d/` or `id/`?

Even now, the transaction shows zero confirmations.
@musickiller I think clickable links works now without an <a/>-tag!

It's in Hindi (Indian), and I do believe that “duniya” means “world” in Hindi.

Here in Denmark we mostly know the word from “Dunya Kebab”. 😋

Wikipedia [agrees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunya) with you: “Dunyā (Дуня) (دُنْيا) is originally an Arabic word that was passed to many other languages such as Persian, Dari, Pashto, Bengali, Punjabi, Urdu, Hindi, Kurdish, Nepali, Turkish, Arumanian, North-Caucasian languages, Malay, Swahili, and Indonesian as well as modern Greek.”
You're right, [@tasty](https://twistnik.com/@tasty) and [@erkanyuksel]( https://twistnik.com/@erkanyuksel) certainly did a lot of good work on the UI!
Haha, that's a good one! 😁
Seems there is some activity on twister-core's issue [#76](https://github.com/miguelfreitas/twister-core/issues/76).
I can't seem to edit my posts anymore, so that might be the end of the TOC…
I can't even “Add new post” anymore! 😱
There is too much noise in the debug.log file for it to be helpful. But I did grep for the first 5 letters of my blog's address and it didn't reveal any errors.

Problem solved: I had put link texts in the markdown for the sidebar, and apparently some js was unamused.

See also [ZeroBlog issue #9](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroBlog/issues/9).

It's another distributed filesystem, yes. I didn't use the fs much, though, the feature that shined was Dmail: distributed, encrypted ‘email’ with builtin spam protection (somewhat like [hashcash](http://hashcash.org/)'s proof-of-work algorithm).

Sam, the author, had many other ideas of what could be implemented on top of Morphis, and it was all good for as long as it lasted, but then he disappeared below the horizon. Very strange.
I might decide to do that as well.
Added a Bitcoin QR code generator.

> So what have you moved to for your micro-blogging?

I have tinkered with [twtxt 🡕](https://github.com/buckket/twtxt), which is basically crossbreed between a traditional unix `~/.plan` file and an Atom/RSS feed: A plaintext file with a timestamp and up to 140 chars of wisdom (although I ungrudgingly disobey that rule whenever I feel it's necessary) on each line. It doesn't scale (at all), and I'll probably ditch it as soon as Zeronet offers a microblogging solution, but it's fun while it lasts.
Please see [post #20](?Post:20) for more about twtxt and microblogging.

Twister store the twists in the DHT. I'm not sure about the format — I've never looked into that.

The idea of storing entries is separate text files is a good idea, methinks, but then I think there should be a counter or a highwater mark somewhere, so that the app knows exactly which files it hasn't seen before. And if the number goes from 00000000.txt to FFFFFFFF.txt, even @erkan will not run out of space. 😉

@musickiller (off-topic, but…) if you liked “Bushes of Love”, surely you will enjoy the [bad lip reading of Bruno Mars 🡕](https://youtu.be/bUcszN8jRB8), which is much better than [the original 🡕](https://youtu.be/fLexgOxsZu0), IMHO.

Welcome, @ulrichard!
How did you find this post, if I may ask?

Oh, and another thing: are the “import” statement and the “dd/” and “id/” extensions an official part of the namecoin namespace?

From [w'pedia 🡕](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holi):
Holi (pronunciation: /ˈhoʊliː/; Sanskrit: होली Holī) is a spring festival in Nepal and India, also known as the festival of colours or the festival of sharing love.

Welcome, @chinanet! Good to see you!! :)

And yes, I think we're all waiting for a social network here. I'm keeping an eye on the [Earthnet Group](/16ybaY9D2XhhCk5GqjpAmBXJ7DXcsMtrkH/) but I'm unsure how close it is to something useful. Also, I'm unaware of other such initiatives.

Anyone?
Welcome to [@b1eeder](/1Pvxkfj3MCrk51XvUEhhXCkCFTKw28i5ot/)!

> I am sure governments and their 3-letter agencies would also be interested in this…

For my purpose it needn't be personally identifiable.
I guess the reason I'd like to see such a map is to assess whether we're unconnected entities or if there's a greater pattern to the story.
But I guess even a depersonalized map could be abused by someone if the intentions were there.

> It's Musickiller or musickiller

Noted and corrected (here and in future posts, I'm not sure I have the energy to find and correct other cases where I used camel case).

> I said I don't really care

If you didn't care you wouldn't have mentioned it, so at least you care a little bit. 😉

> Or may be I just wanted to chat about something because I'm bored

That's a perfectly valid possibility.

Zeronet really needs a social network / microblogging engine.

> Wanna go back to Twister?

Not really. I make do with [twtxt 🡕](https://github.com/buckket/twtxt) until Zeronet offers a social network.

> I thought you had an idea how to make this stuff work in ZeroNet?

I just presented the idea of hosting the twtxt file on Zeronet because I thought it was a neat way of distributing the file and making the whole thing more distributed. But the twtxt community didn't like the idea. E.g., one person said that he would never have started using twtxt had Zeronet been a prerequisite.

I don't mind. Each his own preferences. I do look forward to a social network / microblogging engine on Zeronet, though.
Me too (although I never really doubted).  😊
Perhaps you can see it if I say that Moscow looks like this: `<DstTzInfo 'Europe/Moscow' LMT+2:30:00 STD>`

1. The abbreviation of Copenhagen's timezone is _not_ “CMT”
2. Denmark is _not_ 50 minutes ahead of UTC
3. WTF is “STD”?

> I hope Sam can learn something from all of this

So do I. I just sent him an email that basically said what I wrote above.

When I read Sam's intro on the MORPHiS website I get the feeling that he thinks MORPHiS is gonna save the internet, and his most recent post on /r/morphis suggests that the upcoming MORPHiS will enable Bitcoin mining without proof-of-work. Now, while both of these sound great, I can't help thinking: delusion of grandeur.

Let's hope Sam will prove me wrong…
Blog entry has been updated with an email response from Sam Maloney.

> [cyrax](#comment_1_13dUD5qbY6LaXH9pfh5iDgXHgKjCZPxvZV): I fell he is a complexity man

Surely Sam is entitled to having is own viewpoint about the whole thing, just like I'm entitled to having mine. But yes, the word complex seems to describe the situation very well.
In the beginning the project seemed very promising, so I kind of feel sad and disappointed now. I will probably watch the project from a distance, but I don't see myself getting involved again.
If Sam can indeed save the internet and also provide Bitcoin mining without proof-of-work, he is indeed worthy of praise. He is clearly an idealist with many ideas, but I need something more tangible than just words from the man. It would be great if he succeeded, though.

> [pycole](#comment_1_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH): it may be Disocactus ackermannii (or the related hybrid)

It is definitely not a _D. ackermannii_, nor the _× hybridus_ (or _phyllanthoides_, for that matter). The flowers of those species are much, much bigger and have a different colour. It could still be a _Disocactus_, though. Thanks for the suggestion.

> [meidan](#comment_1_1LeqWgNKQHKdYdy8AREoHprsCEU6cPrTTC): Some type of cactus?

Yes, I'm pretty sure it's an epiphytic cactus. I'm not very good at cacti, though…

> [pycole](#comment_2_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH): My guess is that your node is asking a random (?) set of nodes if they want any content from that site--or if they have newer versions of files on the site.

I was under the impression that data is only shared with peers that have asked for it, but I might be wrong.

> Try visiting the stats page and looking under your site's url, that might give a hint.

Thanks, that was a good idea (except it didn't answer the question). Under said zite the _peers_ column says _1/1/18_ and the _connected_ column shows only one IP address (one of my own), but I'll keep visiting that page to see if any unknown IP addresses turn up.

> [pycole](#comment_3_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH): Quick question: were you looking under your site's url, and clicking the link that lists ip addresses of each node? just making sure.

Yes, I did (except I didn't click the link, I just read the numbers and followed the reference(s)). Now that I clicked the link I can see my own 5 peers + an IP address that is listed 13 times with different ports, which adds up to the _0/1/18_ peers that is currently listed as seeds.

I cannot recognize the IP address that gets listed 13 times but I wonder if it could be a tracker?

> Also, I have another possible idea: some of the 'peers' you see may be your own nodes counted twice (I think zerohello does this?). Again, looking in stats may clarify things.

Yes, that really helped a lot. Thanks!

> [pycole](#comment_4_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH): […] this is the list of trackers.

The IP address (static.217.104.63.178.clients.your-server.de[178.63.104.217]) is not among the trackers. Also, none of the ports are port 15441, which probably means that the connections are from 178.63.104.217 to my node.

`w3m -dump -cols 200 http://127.0.0.1:43110/Stats | grep 178.63.104.217  | wc -l` reveals that said IP address has appr. 50 connections altogether, so more than one zite is “affected”.

My nodes aren't double counted, but 178.63.104.217 (which isn't mine) is counted 13-15 times and none of the connections use the standard port 15441 (instead they use random ports as if 178.63.104.217 is connecting multiple times to my node and not the other way around),

> [pycole](#comment_6_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH): Are any of them using the tor plugin, by any chance?

None of my nodes are using TOR, and there are no *.onion hosts seeding the empty zite.

> [pycole](#comment_8_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH)

😊
[Apparently 🡕](https://caddyserver.com/docs/cli) you need to disable HTTP/2 if you need to use websockets on a secure connection, but even if I do it still doesn't work. 😒

> [musickiller](#comment_32_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ): Can you please describe it a more complex way, than "awesome".

I suggest you visit the last link in the post — it does a very good job of describing how KBFS works. Then try to imagine if you find those features useful or not.

KBFS is an entirely different thing that Sync. It works like a filesystem. And by putting a file into a private folder that has more than one name (separated by a comma), that file is shared by those on the name list.

Files put in the `/keybase/public/yourusername` are accessible to all that have KBFS installed.

> [musickiller](#comment_33_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ): I still don't get, what does this thing do with twitter, reddit, etc.

It doesn't do anything with Twitter or Reddit — or any other website, for that matter. It's a filesystem.

When you start `keybase` (that you can think of as a PGP/GPG key manager) and `kbfsfuse` (which is the actual filesystem thing), a folder named `/keybase` appears on your computer. In that folder you'll find two subfolders, `private` and `public`. Any file that you drop in `/keybase/public/musickiller` will be accessible to _anyone_ who has KBFS installed, and the file is _signed_ with your GPG key so that people can be confident that the file is from you. Any file that you drop in `/keybase/private/musickiller` is accessible by _you only_, from _any_ computer that you control (in this respect KBFS resembles Dropbox), and the file is _encrypted_ with your GPG key. And if you drop a file in, say, `/keybase/private/musickiller,kseistrup` that file will be available (read _and_ write) by both you and me. And the KBFS makes the whole signing / encrypting process automatic.

I haven't put an `index.html` file in my keybase dir, but you can see the other public content here: https://kseistrup.keybase.pub/
If you had KBFS installed, you'd be able to access the content from the `/keybase/public/kseistrup` folder on your own computer.

> [musickiller](#comment_34_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ): Damn, I'm cursed. People tend to describe me only things that I already understand…

Perhaps you ask the wrong questions. I doubt that people deliberately answer your questions in a way that gives you an answer you weren't looking for.

> Hey! I've got an idea of a very useful app for mobile devices: A browser that downloads and updates web pages only on a fast and reliable connection. Cool for reading.

Something akin to [Pocket 🡕](https://getpocket.com/)?

> Should I post it in my blog?) U know.. I'll post it anyway xD

Good idea!

> [musickiller](#comment_35_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ): No, they don't... And usually I don't ask, it usually happens when I make a statement and someone disagrees. They seem to guess my motives wrong. It has started at least 2 weeks ago, or that's when I began to see it.

So what you're saying is: When multiple persons seem to get your statements wrong, it's not because of the way you're expressing yourself, it's because they “seem to guess [your] motives wrong”? Right… 😉

> [musickiller](#comment_37_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ): Have you seen that new project from creators of NXT?

Ardor? Yes, it sounds exciting.

I'll send you an invite in BM when I'm done with this comment. I got them from Chris Coyne, one of the people behind Keybase.

> [musickiller](#comment_38_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ): Can you explain it?

Ardor _is_ NXT 2.0. It has some new features, like side chains. I really can't explain it and I don't have any plans writing a post about it — I'm in no position to do that.

Did you read https://nxtforum.org/core-development-announcements/%28ann%29-ardor-or-nxt-2-0-a-scalable-child-chain-platform ?

> [musickiller](#comment_39_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ): So all I have to do is to find my existing NXT wallets, buy more NXT and wait for Ardor?))

Basically, yes. :)

You can upload just your public key to keybase.io and keep the private key at home.
You can snoop the connection when you ring in your password and see if the password transmitted.
Apart from that you can't know anything, it's all about trust. And yes, that sucks.

> [musickiller](#comment_41_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ): I think that the best storage project would be a distributed web of people that gain credits for storing files of other people and use them for storing their own files.

That system is called [MaidSafe 🡕](http://www.maidsafe.net/), isn't it?

> [meidan](#comment_2_1LeqWgNKQHKdYdy8AREoHprsCEU6cPrTTC): If you use Vili culture you just put the culture in a jar with milk.

I had to look up _viili_ as I didn't know that word. Supposedly it's the Finnish term for the Swedish _filmjölk_. When I were a kid I used to love the _filmjölk_ when we stayed in Sweden during the summer. For many years I thought it was just because of the novelty, but today I know that _filmjölk_ hosts its own unique composition of lactobacilli (and yeasts). Fermentation certainly is an interesting world.
